hints_html: What special kind of matrix is \(\begin{bmatrix}0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\)? What is the norm of this kind of matrix? How can this help you?

hints_raw: What special kind of matrix is <math> \begin{bmatrix}0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} </math>? What is the norm of this kind of matrix? How can this help you?
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Let \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, U = \begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \\ 1& 0 \end{bmatrix}, B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 0& 2 \end{bmatrix}\)

Observe that \(U^{-1}\) = \(U^{T}\) and all entries are real, so U is an orthogonal matrix. This means that \(\begin{Vmatrix}U\end{Vmatrix}\begin{Vmatrix}B\end{Vmatrix} = \begin{Vmatrix}B\end{Vmatrix} = \begin{Vmatrix}A\end{Vmatrix}\)

\(\begin{Vmatrix}B\end{Vmatrix} = 2\)

because the norm of a diagonal matrix is the entry with the largest magnitude.

and therefore, \(\begin{Vmatrix}A\end{Vmatrix} = 2\).

Next, notice that

\(\displaystyle A^{-1} = B^{-1}U^{-1} = B^{-1} U\)

Once again, since U is orthogonal,

\(\begin{Vmatrix}A^{-1}\end{Vmatrix} = \begin{Vmatrix}B^{-1}\end{Vmatrix}\)

As

\(B^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix}1 && 0 \\ 0 && 1/2\end{bmatrix}\)

we have that \(\begin{Vmatrix}B^{-1}\end{Vmatrix} = 1\). Thus

\(\begin{Vmatrix}A\end{Vmatrix}\begin{Vmatrix}A^{-1}\end{Vmatrix} = 2\cdot 1 = 2\)

therefore, cond(A) = 2

statement_html:
Find the norm and condition number of

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} = \left( \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \right)\end{aligned}\]
